alert.note: Alert for Sheridan (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 16 at 1:04PM MDT by NWS Billings
info.description: ...Foothills snowmelt may lead to localized flooding... Warmer temperatures will increase snowmelt over area foothills, and the higher hills of Big Horn and Sheridan counties. While this round of warm temperatures will be shorter and less extreme than what occurred last week, that event has primed the snow to melt faster with subsequent warm periods. If you experienced problems with snowmelt last week, be prepared for additional water issues through Wednesday. A cold front late Monday night will cool temperatures and slow snowmelt through Tuesday. However there will be a lag in runoff working through the system that will likely last into Wednesday. A second concern, that is increasing in potential, is rain falling on snow Tuesday into Tuesday evening. The most likely area for this to occur will be over southern Big Horn and Sheridan county. Rain falling on snow, even cold rain, can result in rapid melting of snow and enhanced flooding concerns. Take any rain falling on snow situation seriously. Water flowing downhill and accumulating in low lying areas may result in localized flooding. Expect increased flows on area creeks, streams, and rivers. Small creeks and streams that originate in the foothills may reach bankfull in some areas with minor flooding a possibility. Water may accumulate near home foundations increasing the chance of basement flooding. Plugged culverts, ditches, and storm drains may result in water flowing over and possibly eroding roadways in spots. Unpaved roads may suddenly thaw and become muddy and impassable. The severity of the impacts will depend on how quickly the snowpack melts, how fast the ground thaws, and any precipitation. While flooding is not imminent, if you have not already done so, now is the time to move equipment and livestock out of low lying areas, and away from waterways. Move any heavy accumulations of snow away from structures and take steps to prevent water from making it into basements. Unplug storm drains and culverts to give water a place to go. Do not drive over flooded roadways as the roadbed may be washed out. Stay tuned to the forecast for the latest temperature and precipitation trends, along with any warnings or advisories that may be issued. Please report any flooding to local law enforcement and have them relay the report to the National Weather Service.
